body:
it seems like #3518 did not entirely fix this issue -- there will be an error if you try to inherit from the subscripted class.

For example, with the following in `example.py`, and building the same way as above:
```python
from typing import Generic, TypeVar

T = TypeVar("T")

print(Generic[T])

class MyGeneric(Generic[T]):
  pass
```

will give:
```python
>>> import example
typing.Generic[~T]
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "example.py", line 7, in init example
    class MyGeneric(Generic[T]):
TypeError: __init__() takes 3 positional arguments but 4 were given
```

_Originally posted by @nikhilmishra000 in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2753#issuecomment-616874842_

comment_data.body:
What needs to be done:
- copy tests from CPython
- fix the implementation in the `Py3ClassCreate` section in `ObjectHandling.c` according to what CPython does here
- adapt/compensate for older Python versions.
Hello, I have also this bug, is someone working on it ?
@GrosFap not that I know of. Help, investigations and PR(s) all welcome. See my comment just above.

I've started to investigate some weeks ago, and I found that this issue was cause by the lack of handling for `__mro_entries__` (I would have won some time by better reading https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2753#issuecomment-616928891)
~~In fact, in Cython, there is no equivalent of `__build_class__`, where `__mro_entries__` is evaluated.
That's why i'm not sure @scoder that a modification of `ObjectHandling.c` would be enough to add this mecanism in class building.~~

I can't remember if I'd already looked at this, but the signature is kind of similar to `__build_class__`, so I feel like I was kind of blind at that time … I'm looking at it right now, and indeed, if we insert an equivalent of CPython `update_bases`, it could do the job.
I will try to do it this weekend (but I don't promise anything, cause I find the quite hard to get into the code and I haven't find the documentation I need — for instance, looking for a simple way to copy a tuple, have to juggle between Cython and CPython code to come up with `PyObject *orig_bases = __Pyx_PyTuple_FromArray(((PyTupleObject*)bases)->ob_item, PyTuple_GET_SIZE(bases))` — I'm very new to CPython/Cython)

@wyfo Don't do `PyObject *orig_bases = __Pyx_PyTuple_FromArray(((PyTupleObject*)bases)->ob_item, PyTuple_GET_SIZE(bases))` - we try to use the C API functions and avoid accessing semi-private details such as `ob_item`. That kind of detail tends to break compatibility with things like PyPy.

Is there a good reason you have to copy it? Under most circumstances tuples should be immutable so there's no advantage to a separate copy. If you *really* do have to copy it then it might be better to do `PyTuple_New` then a loop where you set elements.

If anyone can give me guidance on where exactly to start with this, I'd be more than happy to try and piece a fix together for this, since per #3794, this is one of the main reasons my project which has around 30kloc cannot be Cythonized on the current master version of Cython.

I haven't ever worked on this codebase though so I am not entirely sure on where I need to be looking for this.

milestone.description:
Goals:
– New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
– Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
– Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
– Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Fix inheritance of generic types (PEP-560)
